thread.title: When New York, Chicago face off, the Big Apple wins big-time
thread.title_full: When New York, Chicago face off, the Big Apple wins big-time

title: When New York, Chicago face off, the Big Apple wins big-time
text:
1908: A ride on Chicago’s L cost 5 cents 
1986: A one-way trip on the No. 7 subway line to Flushing was $1 
NUMBER OF STATES 
1908: 46. We were a country without New Mexico, Arizona, Alaska and Hawaii. 
1986: 50 
The winner: New York. It’s not even close. 
Hot dog 
CHICAGO-STYLE VS. N.Y. CLASSIC 
The debate: In Chicago, that dog balances an entire garden on top with yellow mustard, sweet green pickle relish, onion, tomato wedges, pickle spear, sport peppers, and celery salt on a poppy seed roll. New York revels in its simplicity with a Nathan’s hot dog topped with a little spicy brown mustard and sauerkraut. 
The winner: New York, if only because there are fewer toppings to fall on people’s shirts. 
Tourist attraction 
WILLIS TOWER VS. EMPIRE STATE BUILDING 
The debate: The Sears Tower (Ok, it’s really named the Willis Tower now but no one calls it that) is 108 stories, 1,730 feet (with antenna), outreaching the Empire State Building at 102 stories and 1,454 feet with antenna. And, sure, Ferris Bueller visited the Sears Tower on his day off and Batman stood atop it in “The Dark Night,” but King Kong climbed the Empire State Building and Cary Grant waited hours for Deborah Kerr there. 
The winner: New York. A giant gorilla swatting at planes? Cary Grant waiting for the love of his life? We love New Yorker Matthew Broderick, but not that much. 
Buy this photo Charles Rex Arbogast Actor Bill Murray waves to the crowd before throwing out a ceremonial first pitch at a Cubs game in 2012. (AP Photo/Charles Rex Arbogast) BILL KOSTROUN Jerry Seinfeld throwing out the first pitch before a Mets game in 2005. (AP Photo/Bill Kostroun, File) Most rabid celebrity fans 
CUB FANS BILL MURRAY, JOHN CUSACK, EDDIE VEDDER, JIM BELUSHI VS. METS FANS JERRY SEINFELD, CHRIS ROCK, KEVIN JAMES, JON STEWART 
The debate: This is the toughest call of them all and it probably comes down to Murray vs. Seinfeld. 
The winner: Chicago and Murray. Hey, it’s a Cinderella story. 
Frank Sinatra song 
MY KIND OF TOWN VS. NEW YORK, NEW YORK, 
The debate: Mets fans might even vote for Chicago in this one, as “New York, New York” is forever linked to that other N.Y. team and played after every Yankees victory at home. 
The winner: Chicago. Sinatra says “it won’t let you down” and the song’s not nearly as irritatingly overplayed and quoted. 
Buy this photo Dave Pickoff In this Sept. 9, 1969, file photo, a black cat stands in front of the Chicago Cub�s dugout during the first inning of a baseball game against the New York Mets in New York. (AP Photo/Dave Pickoff, File) Buy this photo STEVE MATTEO Sam Sianis, owner of the Billy Goat Tavern in Chicago, sits with his billy goat in the tavern. (AP Photo/Steve Matteo, File) Animals at the ballpark 
THE GOAT VS. THE BLACK CAT 
The debate: A local Chicago bar owner tried to bring his goat to Game 4 of the 1945 World Series at Wrigley Field. The Cubs were up two games to one and had four home games to play. But when William “Billy Goat” Sianis wasn’t allowed to bring his pet into the park, he allegedly cursed the team and said it would never win again as long as his goat was banned. The Cubs lost that game and the series — and haven’t won since. 
In September 1969, as the Cubs were in the process of losing a huge division lead to the Mets, a black cat appeared on the field at Shea Stadium, walked past a Cubs player in the on-deck circle, in front of the Chicago dugout before running away. The Cubs finished their collapse and the Miracle Mets won the World Series. 
The winner: New York. Not only aren’t the Mets cursed, the goat’s name? Murphy. Mets fans hope it’s a name that continues to haunt Cubs fans this year thanks to their playoffs-star-so-far Daniel Murphy. 
Email: yoriok@northjersey.com © 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
